titleStmt.title: [It is generally believed in Washington] and [day and night monotonous]
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was likely composed in December 1864. Since Whitman's subject is the War Department's refusal to allow a general exchange of prisoners, the manuscript may be related to his letter advocating for an exchange, published on December 27, 1864 in the New York Times and the Brooklyn Daily Eagle. The verso may describe the transportation of released Union prisoners to Fortress Monroe (also Fort Monroe) in Virginia, which took place on February 19–20, 1862. The Daily National Intelligencer (Washington, D.C.), for example, covered the arrival of the prisoners at the fort in its February 22, 1862 issue.
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Janel Cayer Elizabeth Lorang Ashley Lawson Tim Jackson

bibl.author: Walt Whitman

revisionDesc.change: added a period to file name @facs

div1.p: It is generally believed in Washington that the President & his family is in favor of a general exchange, & has been but has been for the past year overruled by the head of the war Department & others T The consequences are well known in interiorto those to &all whomix much with the people & the soldiers. the governmentadministration is establ has already established a name for bad faith, which will tell for years to come and the army is far more deeply incensed than appears on the surface.
I know know nothing in history more dastardly than the course of the war department toward

ab.hi: Their blood is on our own heads

ab.del: America," Star Spangled RannerBanner," "Fight for the Uniion," &c.—

div1.ab: day and night monotonous—same thing day after day and night after night—
Visitors—some visitor—Sundays, crowd in front looks up at the windows

Left 19th Feb., 2 at 5 in the morning—marched down to the tug boat,—(4 secesh officers in charge—no guard) mean Wm Alison.—380 privates and 20 officers started from 8—come down the James river within 10 miles of Newport News—at noon barrel of crackers opened—and meat—sang away the night aboard the boat with patriot songs arrived at Fort transferred (men on deck &c salting in like slave ship) to the Express and came down to Fort Monroe, arriving on the 20th at 10 a.m
